metadata.title: Nano-modification of cementitious material: toward a stronger and durable concrete

sections.text:

Nano-modification of cementitious material: toward a stronger and durable concrete
Surendra P. Shah, Pengkun Hou & Maria S. Konsta-Gdoutos
To cite this article: Surendra P. Shah, Pengkun Hou & Maria S. Konsta-Gdoutos (2015): Nanomodification of cementitious material: toward a stronger and durable concrete, Journal of Sustainable Cement-Based Materials, DOI: 10.1080/21650373.2015.1086286

Nano-modification of cementitious material: toward a stronger and durable concrete
Surendra P. Shaha, Pengkun Houb* and Maria S. Konsta-Gdoutosc
aDepartment of Civil Engineering, Northwestern University, Evanston 60201, IL, USA; bSchool of Materials Science and Engineering, University of Jinan, Jinan 250022, Shandong, China;
cDepartment of Civil Engineering, Democritus University of Thrace, Xanthi GR-67100, Greece
(Received 13 April 2015; accepted 6 August 2015)
Nanotechnology in construction and building materials has attracted great attention in recent years. Results demonstrated that nanomodification of cementitious materials can lead to significant improvement of the mechanical property, compactness, and durability. In this paper, based on the major characteristics of nanomaterials when used in cement-based materials, the recent progresses of nanomodification of cementitious materials with the mostly used nanomaterials such as nano-SiO2, nanoclay, nano-Al2O3,and carbon nano materials (carbon nanotubes and nanofibers) are reviewed. Modification effects and their influencing mechanisms of nanomaterials introduced by their specific features, such as the hydration seeding effect, the filling effect, the thixotropy-modifying effect, and the chemical reactivity feature on the properties of cementitious materials are reviewed. It is suggested that a stronger, greener, and more durable cementitious material can be obtained through the help of nanomodification.
Keywords: nanomaterial; cement-based materials; modification

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
With the thriving development of construction and building industry during the last decades in the world, more and more concern has been paid on the costs, the consumption of the natural resources and energy as well as the resulted impacts on the environment. A limited availability of high-quality raw materials, the greenhouse effect caused by CO2 emission during cement/concrete production, and a huge amount of building wastes caused by the demolishment of the improperly designed materials/structures, etc. have threatened the current model of development of this industry. Great efforts have
been made to pursue a more sustainable development model. Among them, enhancement of the properties of cementbased material (in both the fresh and hardened states) has been considered as the most direct way: a more workable concrete mixture helps to reduce the construction costs and a good durability of the concrete results in lesser consumption of the natural resources and energy. And, this has been one of the major themes of the development of construction and building materials science in the last half century: applications of chemical admixtures and supplementary cementitious materials (SCMs), which increase the
*Corresponding author. Email: mse_houpk@ujn.edu.cn

workability, decrease the porosity, optimize the C–S–H gel structure, and improve the durability of concrete, have been increasingly common.
Although great achievements have been made using micrometer fines (SCMs) to enhance the properties of cement-based materials, less work has been done from the smaller scale. With the help of modern micro-observation/computation technology, it has been well recognized that cement-based materials have the nanosized features, including the nano-sized C–S–H gel and the nano-sized pores. As the properties of cement-based materials are determined by their compositions and structures, efforts were made of utilizing nanomaterials in cement-based materials during the last decades for acquiring a better performance from the very bottom side. All these properties are dependent on the features of nanomaterials and their effects on the physiochemical properties of the cementitious materials.
This paper reviews the recent work of utilizing nanomaterials to modify the fresh and hardened properties of cementitious materials. The influencing mechanisms were discussed based on their primary features, i.e. the nano-scale size and the chemical reactivity when used in cement-based materials toward an overall recognition of nanomodification on the properties of cement-based materials.

sections.heading: 2. Nano-sized feature
sections.text:
It is well recognized that novel functionalities can often be introduced with the application of nanomaterials due to their small sizes. Nanomaterials used in cement-based materials are those 0D (nanoparticles), 1D (nanofibers), and 2D (nanofoil) [1] materials with sizes smaller than 100 nm. When added into cementbased materials, nano-sized feature of these materials plays significant effects on the hydration and hardening processes, which finally affects the structures
and performances of the cementitious materials at all ages.

sections.heading: 2.1. Hydration seeding effect
sections.text:
The primary influence of nanomaterial on the properties of cement-based materials has been recognized as the hydration acceleration effect on cement. The reaction of cement with water is a dissolution–precipitation process, i.e. unhydrates dissolve when meeting water, forming the saturated/oversaturated ion solution, and the hydrates precipitate after the formation of the hydration seeds according to the nucleation theory.[2] Due to the small size of the nanomaterial, it acts as the hydration seed during the precipitation process and the C–S–H gel formation around the nanomaterials were more, contributing to the enhancement of the accelerated dissolution/hydration of cementitious materials.[3] This theory has been verified by the setting and the earlyage mechanical property gain characteristics, and work of assessing the hydration heat of tricalcium silicate (C3S) using heat calorimetry technique [4] and modeling [4] has also been conducted. Hou et al.’s work showed that the Ca ion concentration of cement solution increases with the addition of nano-SiO2, and an identical conclusion was drawn by Singh as shown in Figure 1.[5] It shows that the Ca ion concentration at the very early age decreases in the nano-SiO2-added C3S–water system, which has been related to the formation of secondary/additional C–S–H that starts at the early stage of C3S hydration. SEM images directly suggested that nanomaterial acts as the seed of the C–S–H gel formation at the initial stage of cement hydration, [6] and this process has been schematically illustrated by Figure 2 [4]: C–S–H seeds from the hydration of the pozzolanic reaction of nano-SiO2 accelerate the formation of C–S–H gel and less porous structure can thus be resulted.
D ow

Similar mechanisms were attributed to the influences of other types of nanomaterial on the hydration/hardening properties of cement-based materials and intensive investigations on hydration heat, non-evaporable water content measurements, and more directly on the mechanical property gain were conducted. According to Nazari and Riahi, a 70% compressive strength improvement of concrete can be achieved with an addition of 4% nanosilica by mass of cement [7]; in a separate study, Shih et al. showed that a 0.6% colloidal nano-SiO2 (CNS) addition can improve
the compressive strength of cement paste by 43.8% [8]; and Li et al. found that when 3 and 5% nano-SiO2 were added to plain cement mortar, compressive strength increased by 13.8 and 17.5% at 28 days, respectively.[9] Liu et al. [10] found that the compressive strength of cement mortar with addition of 1 wt.% nano-CaCO3 was increased by 111.2 and 108.6% at 7 and 28 days, respectively. The study conducted by Nazari et al. [11] suggested that the compressive strength of cement concrete was increased by 14.0 and 16.7% at 7 and 28 days, respectively, when 1 wt.% nano-Al2O3 was introduced.
The hydration acceleration effect of nanomaterials on cement has been taken to tackle with the problem of the slow property gain of high-volume SCMs systems, such as fly ash and blastfurnace slag, especially at early ages. Results showed that nanomaterials, for example, nano-SiO2, nano-Al2O3, nano-limestone, nanoclay, and nano-Fe2O3, when introduced at an optimal dosage, increase the property gain rate, and the final property
Figure 2. Schematic of the hydration process.[4]

of SCMs-replaced cement-based materials significantly, and a greater improvement is seen in a greater dosage of SCM system. Using nanotechnology, it is expected that the CO2 footprint can be lowered, and greener and more sustainable cement-based materials can be resulted.[12–14] For the mechanisms accounting for the improvements, the hydration acceleration effect of nanomaterials on both cement and SCMs have been reported. Li’s work suggested that fly ash hydration extent can be improved in the saturated lime solution when nanoSiO2 was added (Figure 3, weight increment was used as the index for hydration extent evaluation) and the seeding effect has been ascribed to the hydration extent enhancement.[15] Detailed study on the ion concentration and pH value evolution of the nanomaterial-added system suggested that the enhanced dissolution of cement results in high alkalinity of the solution (Figure 4), leading to a high reaction extent of the SCMs.[16]

sections.heading: 2.2. Filling effect
sections.text:
Pores in cement-based materials act as the transport routes for deteriorative agents that finally lead to the deterioration of the structures. For acquiring a good performance of cementitious material in harsh environment, a compact structure is desired and this can be achieved with the application of fine powders such as finely ground pozzolans. With the help of these fine powders, service life of current concrete structure has been extended, and this technique has been the foundation of high-strength/high-performance concrete. However, due to the micro-scale nature of the pozzolans, as well as their relatively low reactivity, there is a limit of improving service life of concrete with these materials due to the intrinsic nano-feature of concrete structures, especially the pore system. To handle this, many researchers have been seeking assistance from the
combination of powders of various sizes by following various particle packing models to make a dense concrete with lesser binder, during which nanomaterials have been used (Figure 5). It shows that a dense and homogeneous skeleton of UHPC has been obtained with a relatively low binder amount [17–19] with the aid of the particle packing theory and the use of nanomaterials. The filling effect,[20] especially for those reactivity-inert nanomaterials [21], seeding effect, hydration acceleration effect, etc. are accounted for the improvement of the compactness of the concrete body at the nano-size scale scope (Figure 6).

sections.heading: 2.3. Thixotropy-modifying effect
sections.text:
The specific surface area of nanomaterial could be one order of magnitude greater than that of silica fume, which has been normally regarded as the finest component used in conventional cementitious materials. The great specific surface area has great influences on the application of nanomaterials in cementitious materials as more water is needed to get it wetted, and less water is remained for lubricating the mix. Meanwhile, the physical structure of nanoparticles would change and affect the thixotropy behavior of cementitious materials.
With the development of the very flowable self-consolidating concrete (SCC), it is reported that some specific nanomaterials can work as the thixotropy-modifying agents to be taken advantage of to acquire a desired property: a mix of high flowability, which stiffens rapidly when at rest, so as to reduce the formwork pressure which has originally been designed to withstand the hydraulic pressure with the rise of the casting SCC structure. Influences of nanoclay on the rheological properties of SCC have been intensively studied at the Center for Advanced Cement-Based Materials at Northwestern University,

Results demonstrated that through proper proportioning of fly ash, superplasticizers, and a small addition of nanoclay (<1% by mass of binder, the nanosized attapulgite clay), it is possible to design an SCC mix that experiences high flowability during casting and high green strength immediately after placement, which can effectively reduce SCC formwork pressure. This has been studied by applying the programmed vertical pressure on SCC and measuring the lateral pressure simulated as the formwork pressure, and the results are shown in Figure 7.
It shows in Figure 7 that nanoclay significantly reduced lateral pressure of SCC: as much as 40% reduction of the lateral pressure can be obtained when 0.33% nanoclay was added at 2-h casting time (the applied vertical pressure was used to simulate the hydraulic pressure exerted by the rise of the casting SCC structure). An in-depth study on the mechanism of the reduction of the lateral pressure was conducted through assessment of the rehological property evolution of cement pastes using rheometer and tack test. It was found that both water absorption of nanoclay (200 times higher than its weight) and its effects on the structure rebuilding capability (flocculation) contribute to the increase of the stiffness of the fresh paste upon the removal of the sheer, which finally results in the increase of the shape stability of SCC [22]. More recent work conducted by the tack test and the low-amplitude oscillatory shear rheometry reported by Kawashima (Figure 8) suggested that the increase of the flocculation caused by the clays accelerate the immediate recovery/ rebuilding of the structure, increasing the

sections.heading: 3. Chemical reactivity
sections.text: One of the mechanisms of nanomaterials’ influences on cementitious materials is that the C–S–H gel structures/properties of cementitious materials can be altered due to the involvement of the chemical reaction of nanomaterial in cement hydration. The most commonly reported chemicalreactive nanomaterial is nano-SiO2.

sections.heading: 3.1. Pozzolanic reactivity of nano-SiO2
sections.text:
As the most widely used nanomaterial in cementitious materials, nano-SiO2 has attracted great attention of the researchers.[24] Hou et al. [25] studied the pozzolanic reactivity of nano-SiO2/silica fume of various sizes by mixing them with Ca(OH)2 (CH) agent at the mass ratio of 1:4 at a w/b of 2.0 to simulate a cement–nano-SiO2/silica fume system. TGA technique was used to quantify the CH content of the systems at different ages. By correlating the CH-consuming rate of nano-SiO2/silica fume, the chemical reactivity has been quantified. The slope of the regression line of the scatter graph of the CH content vs. the time as shown in Figure 9 has been used to reflect the reactivity and the reaction rate constants of different nano-SiO2s and silica fume, and the results are listed in Table 1, from where the apparent reaction rate constant and normalized reaction rate constants (normalized by the specific surface area of the pozzolans) are shown. It revealed that the pozzolanic reaction of nano-SiO2 is of the first order and the reaction rate constant of nano-SiO2-4 nm is about one order of magnitude bigger than that of silica fume. It also suggested from the results that both chemical composition and particle size may be crucial
Figure 8. Tack tester and the typical normal force vs. shear time (left) and peak force vs. plate velocity for cement pastes with 0, 0.2, and 0.5% nanoclay addition(right).[23]
D ow

factors that govern the properties of highSi supplementary materials.

sections.heading: 3.2. Influences of chemical reactivity on the properties of the hydration products
sections.text:
Due to the high pozzolanic reactivity of nano-SiO2, additional C–S–H gel formed has been ascribed to the enhancement of the compressive strength, the reduction of the porosity, and the improvement of chemical resistivity. Gaitero and his co-authors investigated the calcium-leaching resistivity of nano-SiO2-added cement-based materials.[26] They observed that degradation due to the accelerated calcium leaching was significantly less for nano-SiO2 addition as compared to that by micro-silica addition. They reported that nano-SiO2 particles increase the average length of the silicate chains of C–S–H gel, as shown in Figure 10.
Many researches have suggested that the morphology of the cementitious materials become more compact when nanoparticles were introduced. The current authors compared the hydrates morphology of nano-SiO2 with that of silica fume, and SEM images (Figure 11) showed that a compacter micro-structure (with lower calcium to silica ratio) of the pozzolanic reaction products is formed when compared to that of silica fume. A comparable compacter C–S–H gel structure formed by nano-SiO2 particle has also been reported by Thomas and Cheng [4] and Singh et al. [5]. Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) image showed that bigger hydration grain size can be seen in the greater nano-SiO2added sample, 600 nm vs. 800–1200 nm in 1 and 5% NS-added cement pastes [3].
More recently, the most popular 2D nanomaterial, graphene oxide (GO) nanosheet has been introduced into cementitious materials. Beside the often-

reported benefits introduced by nanomaterials, it was found that the 2D nanosheet acts as a template for the formation of the hydration products of cement. Figure 12 depicts the formation of the flower-like crystals in the GO nanosheet-added cementitious material system. It was found that when the content of GO was 0.03%, the cement composites exhibited remarkable increase in tensile strength (78.6%), flexural strength (60.7%), and compressive strength (38.9%) comparing with those without GO. The results suggested that GO nanosheets played a vital role in effectively regulating the microstructure of
hydration crystals, distinctly reducing its brittleness and significantly enhancing the toughness and this was verified by the stress–strain curve of the cementitious materials as shown in Figure 13.
Two typical types of C–S–H gel, the inner (compacter) and outer (looser) C–S–H gel, are widely reported in cementitious materials and nanomechanical investigation verified their existence. It is accepted that the inner C–S–H gel of cement hydrates has a denser morphology and stronger mechanical property, and has always been grouped as C–S–H gel of high elastic modulus. The influence of nano-SiO2 on the nanomechanical

property of C–S–H gel has been proved by the nanoindentation tests.[6]
It can be seen in Figure 14 that when CNS was added, the high-stiffness gel region is more pronounced, indicating an increase in high-stiffness C–S–H gel. Gaitero et al. [26] and Mondal [27] compared the nanoindentation results of 6 and 18% CNS-added pastes and also found that the latter has a higher proportion of the high-stiffness C–S–H gel. All these results showed that the compact microstructure of nanomaterialmodified cementitious materials resulting from the additional C–S–H gel or accelerated cement hydration could be
attribute to these improvement, and this was clarified by the nanoindentation test on other nanomaterial-modified cementitious materials, carbon nanotube (CNT) [28], described in greater detail in a subsequent section. These benefits were applied in various cementitious materials for improving the weak zone, Interficial Transition Zone (ITZ) of recycled aggregates is one of the examples. Work conducted by Mukharjee and Barai [29] suggested that the porosity of ITZ decreases with the introduction of nanoSiO2, resulting in an improved micromechanical property and compacter microstructure of the ITZ.

sections.heading: 3.3. Utilization of the high chemical reactivity of nano-SiO2 for surface treatment
sections.text:
Recognizing the great benefits of nanoSiO2 on the hydration and C–S–H gel properties of cementitious materials, great attempts have been made to take its advantages for making a more durable concrete. Considering its fine particle size and super-high reactivity, Cardenas and her co-workers primarily made effect of using nano-SiO2 for enhancing the surface quality of hardened cementitious materials. During their work, nano-SiO2 particles were embedded in the pore of hardened cementitious materials by electrokinetic method. It was revealed that a thickness of about several hundred microns thickness of nano-SiO2-modified
cementitious materials can be obtained, [30, 31] which contributes to the great improvement of the durability, i.e. improvement of the sulfate and chloride ion resistance. More recently, Sánchez et al. also reported using CNS migration for the sealing of the hardened cementitious materials [32] and it was found that pozzolanic reaction of the penetrated nano-SiO2 contributes to the improved surface quality. The electrokinetic technique used to drive nanoparticle into hardened cementitious materials can be schematically illustrated in Figure 15.
It is easy to understand that it is the prerequisite of the penetration of silicate material into hardened cementitious materials to achieve an improved surface quality through the pozzolanic reaction with

the cement hydration product of CH. For acquiring a higher penetration depth, the precursor of nano-SiO2, ethyl silicate, tetraethyl silicate (TEOS), has been recently used in cementitious materials.[33] As a kind of saline, TEOS is well known for its application in the consolidation and preservation of art works, but unlike other types of saline, TEOS has rarely been used in cementitious materials. It is reported that nano-SiO2 cluster forms by the in situ hydrolysis of TEOS in following Equation (1),[34] during which process the hydrolysis byproduct, ethanol, evaporates easily due to its existence at the superficial part of hardened cementitious materials, and has rare influence on the properties. Mercury Intrusion Porosimetry (MIP) and SEM tests apparently revealed the filling effect of the newly formed nano-SiO2 cluster (Figure 16).[35] Pozzolanic reactivity measurement showed that this newly formed nano-SiO2 reacts with CH, forming additional C–S–H gel, which potentially benefits the physiochemical structure of cementitious materials’ matrix: pores were filled and the polymerization degree of the SiO4 tetrahedra of the TEOStreated C–S–H gel increased, showing the potential of persisting an improved
environment resistivity. Study conducted by Pigino et al. [33] revealed that the resistance to carbonization and sulfate resistance of cement concrete increased (Figure 17) when TEOS treatment was applied. It is known that the deterioration/dissolving of CH crystal in hardened cementitious material is a primary form of deterioration,[36] thus, the reduction of CH content and densification of the surface structure is promising for the improvement of the quality of the entire concrete structure.

Nano-MgO is another newly explored chemical reactive nanocomponent in cementitious material. By taking its gentle expansion during reaction with water, MgO has the great advantage for making shrinkage-compensated cementitious materials, which has been used in mass concrete and proven to be more effective than the CH or AFt expansion agents due to its less requirement of water.[37] Reza recently reported the influence of nanoMgO on the microstructure and compressive strength of cement composites.[38] The results from the treated composites
Figure 15. Scheme of migration cell setup for hardened cement.[32]

compared to those of the plain indicated that the compressive strength of sample containing 1% nano-MgO of binder by weight increased by 103 and 80% at 7 and 28 days, respectively, and that the flexural strength were 95 and 70% higher than those of the plain composite, respectively. SEM images revealed that the microstructure of the composites with nano-MgO were more compact and homogeneous than that of plain composite because of expansive effect of nano-MgO.
Although aluminate oxide is a common component in cementitious
materials, rare evidence has been reported for its evolvement in the chemical reaction of cementitious materials. Recently, Phoo-ngernkham deduced the formation of additional calcium aluminosilicate hydrate and sodium aluminosilicate hydrate (NASH) or geopolymer gel in geopolymer matrix after the addition of nano-Al2O3 particle [39] (Figure 18). However, in his work, the formation of NASH was drawn from the broad hump of amorphous gel but no direct evidence on its evolvement in chemical reaction was shown and this has been verified by
Figure 17. Results of the carbonation depth in w/c 0.45 and in w/c 0.65 samples after 25 days in the carbonation chamber (dk = mean carbonation depth).

4. Nano-modified cementitious composites: Carbon Nanotube and Carbon Nanofiber reinforced pastes and mortars
By manipulating the structure of the material at the nanoscale such as with nanoparticles and nanoscale fibers new multifunctional, high-performance cementitious nanocomposites that could be used in a variety of applications can be developed. As already mentioned, nanoparticles have been found to improve the pore structure of conventional concrete, accelerate the C–S–H gel formation, and enhance the compressive and flexural strength as well as the durability of the cementitious matrix.[41] Similarly, the reinforcing ability of carbon nanotubes (CNT) and nanofibers was proven to substantially improve strength, the fracture characteristics and durability of cementi-
tious nanocomposites [28, 42–45]. The considerable challenge in fully exploiting the properties of CNT and carbon nanofibers as reinforcement in a composite is attributed to the lack of the fiber dispersion in the material matrix. The results of experimental studies on CNT/cement and Carbon Nanofiber (CNF)/cement specimens converge to the point that the addition of CNT or nanofibers improves the mechanical and electrical properties of the nanocomposite material under the condition that effective dispersion of nanofibers in the cement paste has been achieved. Konsta-Gdoutos et al. [28] achieved effective dispersion of CNTs by applying ultrasonic energy along with the use of a surfactant (SFC) and observed that beyond the necessity for ultrasonication, there is an optimum ratio of surfactant to CNTs for good dispersion. More recently, Metaxa applied this dispersion method on four different types of CNFs and investigated the appropriate amount of ultrasonic energy and the surfactant to CNF ratio (SFC/CNF) for effective dispersion [45]. Results concluded that
Figure 18. XRD of geopolymer pastes at 28 days with various nano-Al2O3 (1, 2, and 3%).[39]
D ow
nl oa

20 15
proper dispersion is achieved with the use of a superplasticizer, due to its ability to disperse both cement particles and CNTs or CNFs.
Konsta-Gdoutos studied the mechanical performance of the Multi-Walled Carbon Nanotube (MWCNT)/CNFs reinforced cement pastes by fracture mechanics tests on prismatic specimens of 20 × 20 × 80 mm.[28, 44] Before testing, a 6-mm notch was introduced to the specimens using a water-cooled diamond saw. The test was performed using an 89- kN MTS servo-hydraulic, closed-loop testing machine. A clip gauge was used to measure the crack mouth opening displacement (CMOD), which was used as a feedback to produce a stable fracture at a rate of 0.012 mm/min. The Young’s modulus was calculated from the load vs. CMOD results using the two-parameter fracture model by Jenq and Shah [46]. According to their results (shown in Figure 19(a)), the samples reinforced with nanofibers at all ages exhibit higher flexural strength than plain cement paste. In particular, an increase up to 25% is achieved when MWCNTs are utilized at an amount of 0.048% per weight of cement. The use of CNFs results in an increase of the flexural strength up to 45%. Comparing the two nanocomposites, it is observed that despite the fact that MWCNTs exhibit a higher aspect ratio due to their smaller diameter
and larger amounts of nanotubes is reinforcing the cement matrix since the concentration of the fibers is constant, CNFs provide the matrix with the ability to carry higher flexural loads at lower strains. This increase in the flexural strength seems to be the highest published so far with the lowest amount of MWCNTs. Until now, the addition of the MWCNTs in cementitious matrices has resulted in either a decrease or smaller increase, up to 25%, of the flexural strength [47, 48]. Similar to the flexural strength results, samples reinforced with carbon fibers at the nanoscale exhibit improved Young’s modulus over OPC specimens. An increase of the Young’s modulus of 44–50% over plain cement specimens is achieved with the use of MWCNTs, while in the case of the samples with CNFs, an increase of at least 50% is observed (Figure 19(b)).
Results from nanoindentation experiments by the same authors revealed that effectively dispersed MWCNTs provide a unique role in cement-based materials. The nanoindentation results, shown in Figure 20, suggest that MWCNTs can strongly modify and reinforce the nanostructure of the cementitious matrix. Compared to plain cement matrix, nanocomposites reinforced with either short or long MWCNTs at different amounts up to 0.08% per weight of cement, appear to have a higher amount

of high-stiffness C–S–H and reduced nanoporosity. Reasonably, the nanoindentation results can also provide an indirect method of estimating the volume fraction of the capillary pores.[49] It is observed from Figure 20 that the probability of Young’s modulus below 10 GPa, which corresponds to the porous phase, is significantly reduced for the samples with MWCNTs, indicating that the MWCNTs reduce the amount of fine pores by filling the area between the C–S–H gel. Typically, changes in the nanostructure affect the transport properties, namely the properties that are related with the movement of the water in the pores. As nanoindentation results implied significant changes in the nanostructure of the composites, the authors conducted autogenous shrinkage experiments to determine the effect of the MWCNTs on the early strain capacity of the cementitious matrix. According to these results (shown in Figure 21), when compared to the neat cement paste, MWCNT nanocomposites exhibit lower autogenous shrinkage. Furthermore, specimens reinforced with a higher amount of MWCNTs demonstrate even lower autogenous shrinkage. The shrinkage development is known to be
proportional to the amount of the fine pores (pores with diameter < 20 nm) in the binder at early ages.[50] Higher percentage of the volume fraction of small pores in a cementitious system at early ages leads to the increase of autogenous shrinkage. Due to their small diameters (20–40 nm), MWCNTs appear to reduce the amount of fine pores. This leads to the reduction of the capillary stresses expressed through a substantial reduction of the autogenous shrinkage, at least 30% and near 40%. The whole process results in a beneficial effect on the early strain capacity and the transport properties of the MWCNT and CNF nanocomposites as very low volume MWCNT and CNF additions demonstrate the ability to control cracking resulting to volume changes due to the autogenous shrinkage
Most recent and ongoing research by Konsta-Gdoutos and Shah deals with scaling up from paste nanocomposites to Portland cement mortars, reinforced with MWCNTs. Three-point bending tests on 4 × 4 × 16-cm typical prismatic mortar and paste specimens, and 2 × 2 × 8-cm notched specimens confirmed that the neat cement paste and mortar flexular strengths range between the values of 5.5

and ≅6.0 MPa (Figure 22). It should be noted here that the amount of cement in cement pastes is three times the amount of cement in the mortar mixes. A comparison between pastes and mortars, both reinforced with 0.1% per weight of cement CNTs, is shown in Figure 23. Interestingly, and despite the fact that the estimated MWCNT count, the number of fibers, in this case MWCNT, which are theoretically evenly distributed assuming
perfect dispersion in a unit volume of the matrix (according to ACI 544.1R-96: Report on Fiber Reinforced Concrete) of the paste nanocomposites is three times higher (8.26 × 1011) than that of the mortars (3.61 × 1011), the flexural strength of the MWCNT reinforced mortar is 64% higher than the strength of the corresponding MWCNT paste. Analogous results are shown in Figure 24, where the modulus of elasticity of the mortar nanocomposite was found 111.17% higher. A comparison of mortars and pastes reinforced with approximately the same MWCNT count can be seen in Figure 25. As mentioned previously, the MWCNT count corresponding to 0.1% per weight of cement-reinforced mortar is 3.61 × 1011. A MWCNT amount of 0.048% per weight of cement provides to a cement paste mix an estimated MWCNT count of 3.98 × 1011. It is observed that even though the MWCNT count is the same in both paste and mortar specimens the nanoreinforced mortar’s flexular strength is pproximately 1.7 times higher than the MWCNT paste strength.
It is of interest to note here that so far results in the literature report either a decrease or occasionally only a marginal increase in modulus of rupture and the Young`s modulus for both cement pastes and mortars reinforced with MWCNTs. In our pastes and mortars, however, both the modulus of rupture and modulus of

elasticity increase greatly in all our nanoreinforced mixes, at all ages. This phenomenal increase in the mechanical properties of the nanocomposites, achieved by the use of a very low amount of CNTs, can be safely attributed to the result of an effective dispersion.
One important deterioration mechanism affecting any reinforced concrete application is the corrosion of steel reinforcement. The half-cell potential method is a widely used, simple technique to evaluate the corrosion status of the reinforcement. In this context, half-cell potential tests were conducted on MWCNT-reinforced mortars, following the ASTM C876 [51] guidelines, to determine the probability of active corrosion. The half-cell potential difference between the working electrodes and a Cu/CuSO4 electrode placed in the solution was measured using a high-impedance voltmeter. A reinforcing steel rebar was included in mortar cylindrical specimens to monitor the onset and course of corrosion due to an accelerated corrosion process of the steel. Specimens were stored in the curing room (RH > 98%, T = 20 + 1″5 °C) for 24 h. After being demoulded, the specimens were cured in lime-saturated water at 20 °C for 28 days, then left to dry for 24 h, and covered
with Araldite®. Then they were immersed in 3.5% NaCl solution until tested.
In every accelerated corrosion experiment following ASTM C876, values more negative than the threshold value of −350 mV signal a greater than 90% probability of an active corrosion process. Values between 200 and 350 mV correspond to an area of uncertain or questionable corrosion process. It is observed from Figure 26 that the neat mortar specimens enter the questionable area of values more negative of −200 mV approximately in day 18. Specimens entered the active corrosion area, reaching half-cell potential values more negative than −350 mV around day 25. They remained in active corrosion state for another 30 days, until the end of the experiment. Mortar specimens reinforced with 0.1 wt.% MWCNTs also entered the questionable area around day 18. The recorded half-cell potential values of the 0.1 wt.% MWCNT mortars, however, remained in the questionable area with values between −200 and −300 mV until day 65, where the accelerated corrosion experiment ended. It is reasonable to conclude therefore, that the addition of 0.1 wt.% MWCNTs provides a protection against the ingress of chloride ions and significantly increases corrosion

resistance; hence, this mortar nanocomposite never entered an active corrosion state. On the other hand, the half-cell potential of the 0.5 wt.% MWCNT mortars started dropping also at day 18, and continued dropping to more negatives values below the threshold level of −350 mV until the end of the experiment. A plausible explanation may include the occurrence of galvanic corrosion, due to the large volume of CNTs in the mix. Further testing is on the way to elucidate these findings.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusions
sections.text:
By analyzing the characteristics of nanomaterials used in cement-based materials, the influences of nanomodification on the properties of cement-based materials were reviewed. The following conclusions were drawn from the current development of this technique.
(1) The nano-sized feature of the nanomaterials contribute to the
modifications of hydration of cement, compaction degree of the structure, and alternation of the thixotropy behavior of the fresh cementitious materials. All these effects can be explored to make a stronger, greener, and workable concrete. (2) The chemical reactivity of nanomaterials can be taken advantage of to increase the mechanical property, modify the morphology, optimize the C–S–H gel structure, and enhance the nanomechanical property of cement-based materials, which showed great capability of enhancing the durability of concrete. (3) Recent advances in the field on nanotechnology have developed advantageous carbon nanoscale fibers such as CNTs and nanofibers, making possible the development of high-performance, multifunctional, and more durable cementitious nanocomposites,
Figure 26. Half-cell potential readings for 0.1 and 0.5 wt.% MWCNT mortars. A control mix of neat Portland cement mortar is included for comparison.

referenceMentions.context: Nanomaterials used in cement-based materials are those 0D (nanoparticles), 1D (nanofibers), and 2D (nanofoil) [1] materials with sizes smaller than 100 nm.

unhydrates dissolve when meeting water, forming the saturated/oversaturated ion solution, and the hydrates precipitate after the formation of the hydration seeds according to the nucleation theory.[2] Due to the small size of the nanomaterial, it acts as the hydration seed during the precipitation process and the C–S–H gel formation around the nanomaterials were more, contributing to the enhancement of the accelerated dissolution/hydration of cementitious materials.

[2] Due to the small size of the nanomaterial, it acts as the hydration seed during the precipitation process and the C–S–H gel formation around the nanomaterials were more, contributing to the enhancement of the accelerated dissolution/hydration of cementitious materials.[3] This theory has been verified by the setting and the earlyage mechanical property gain characteristics, and work of assessing the hydration heat of tricalcium silicate (C3S) using heat calorimetry technique [4] and modeling [4] has also been conducted.

’s work showed that the Ca ion concentration of cement solution increases with the addition of nano-SiO2, and an identical conclusion was drawn by Singh as shown in Figure 1.[5] It shows that the Ca ion concentration at the very early age decreases in the nano-SiO2-added C3S–water system, which has been related to the formation of secondary/additional C–S–H that starts at the early stage of C3S hydration.

SEM images directly suggested that nanomaterial acts as the seed of the C–S–H gel formation at the initial stage of cement hydration, [6] and this process has been schematically illustrated by Figure 2 [4]: C–S–H seeds from the hydration of the pozzolanic reaction of nano-SiO2 accelerate the formation of C–S–H gel and less porous structure can thus be resulted.

SEM images directly suggested that nanomaterial acts as the seed of the C–S–H gel formation at the initial stage of cement hydration, [6] and this process has been schematically illustrated by Figure 2 [4]: C–S–H seeds from the hydration of the pozzolanic reaction of nano-SiO2 accelerate the formation of C–S–H gel and less porous structure can thus be resulted.
According to Nazari and Riahi, a 70% compressive strength improvement of concrete can be achieved with an addition of 4% nanosilica by mass of cement [7]; in a separate study, Shih et al.

Li’s work suggested that fly ash hydration extent can be improved in the saturated lime solution when nanoSiO2 was added (Figure 3, weight increment was used as the index for hydration extent evaluation) and the seeding effect has been ascribed to the hydration extent enhancement.[15] Detailed study on the ion concentration and pH value evolution of the nanomaterial-added system suggested that the enhanced dissolution of cement results in high alkalinity of the solution (Figure 4), leading to a high reaction extent of the SCMs.

It was found that both water absorption of nanoclay (200 times higher than its weight) and its effects on the structure rebuilding capability (flocculation) contribute to the increase of the stiffness of the fresh paste upon the removal of the sheer, which finally results in the increase of the shape stability of SCC [22].

As the most widely used nanomaterial in cementitious materials, nano-SiO2 has attracted great attention of the researchers.[24] Hou et al.
[25] studied the pozzolanic reactivity of nano-SiO2/silica fume of various sizes by mixing them with Ca(OH)2 (CH) agent at the mass ratio of 1:4 at a w/b of 2.
33% nanoclay addition (both mixes had a slump flow of 60 ± 2 cm).[52]
5% nanoclay addition(right).[23] Journal of Sustainable Cement-Based Materials 7

Gaitero and his co-authors investigated the calcium-leaching resistivity of nano-SiO2-added cement-based materials.[26] They observed that degradation due to the accelerated calcium leaching was significantly less for nano-SiO2 addition as compared to that by micro-silica addition.
A comparable compacter C–S–H gel structure formed by nano-SiO2 particle has also been reported by Thomas and Cheng [4] and Singh et al.

property of C–S–H gel has been proved by the nanoindentation tests.[6] It can be seen in Figure 14 that when CNS was added, the high-stiffness gel region is more pronounced, indicating an increase in high-stiffness C–S–H gel.
[26] and Mondal [27] compared the nanoindentation results of 6 and 18% CNS-added pastes and also found that the latter has a higher proportion of the high-stiffness C–S–H gel.
[26] and Mondal [27] compared the nanoindentation results of 6 and 18% CNS-added pastes and also found that the latter has a higher proportion of the high-stiffness C–S–H gel.

All these results showed that the compact microstructure of nanomaterialmodified cementitious materials resulting from the additional C–S–H gel or accelerated cement hydration could be attribute to these improvement, and this was clarified by the nanoindentation test on other nanomaterial-modified cementitious materials, carbon nanotube (CNT) [28], described in greater detail in a subsequent section.

Work conducted by Mukharjee and Barai [29] suggested that the porosity of ITZ decreases with the introduction of nanoSiO2, resulting in an improved micromechanical property and compacter microstructure of the ITZ.

It was revealed that a thickness of about several hundred microns thickness of nano-SiO2-modified cementitious materials can be obtained, [30, 31] which contributes to the great improvement of the durability, i.

also reported using CNS migration for the sealing of the hardened cementitious materials [32] and it was found that pozzolanic reaction of the penetrated nano-SiO2 contributes to the improved surface quality.
Effect of nano-SiO2 on the elastic modulus of cement paste.[6] Journal of Sustainable Cement-Based Materials 11

For acquiring a higher penetration depth, the precursor of nano-SiO2, ethyl silicate, tetraethyl silicate (TEOS), has been recently used in cementitious materials.[33] As a kind of saline, TEOS is well known for its application in the consolidation and preservation of art works, but unlike other types of saline, TEOS has rarely been used in cementitious materials.

It is reported that nano-SiO2 cluster forms by the in situ hydrolysis of TEOS in following Equation (1),[34] during which process the hydrolysis byproduct, ethanol, evaporates easily due to its existence at the superficial part of hardened cementitious materials, and has rare influence on the properties.

Mercury Intrusion Porosimetry (MIP) and SEM tests apparently revealed the filling effect of the newly formed nano-SiO2 cluster (Figure 16).[35] Pozzolanic reactivity measurement showed that this newly formed nano-SiO2 reacts with CH, forming additional C–S–H gel, which potentially benefits the physiochemical structure of cementitious materials’ matrix: pores were filled and the polymerization degree of the SiO4 tetrahedra of the TEOStreated C–S–H gel increased, showing the potential of persisting an improved environment resistivity.
[33] revealed that the resistance to carbonization and sulfate resistance of cement concrete increased (Figure 17) when TEOS treatment was applied.

It is known that the deterioration/dissolving of CH crystal in hardened cementitious material is a primary form of deterioration,[36] thus, the reduction of CH content and densification of the surface structure is promising for the improvement of the quality of the entire concrete structure.

By taking its gentle expansion during reaction with water, MgO has the great advantage for making shrinkage-compensated cementitious materials, which has been used in mass concrete and proven to be more effective than the CH or AFt expansion agents due to its less requirement of water.[37] Reza recently reported the influence of nanoMgO on the microstructure and compressive strength of cement composites.
[37] Reza recently reported the influence of nanoMgO on the microstructure and compressive strength of cement composites.[38] The results from the treated composites Figure 15.
Scheme of migration cell setup for hardened cement.[32] 12 S.

Recently, Phoo-ngernkham deduced the formation of additional calcium aluminosilicate hydrate and sodium aluminosilicate hydrate (NASH) or geopolymer gel in geopolymer matrix after the addition of nano-Al2O3 particle [39] (Figure 18).
Ca and Si ion mapping images of TEOS-treated mortar.[34]
other work.[22] Finally, it was shown by Fan et al.
[40] that the addition of nanokaolinite clay can substantially increase durability.

As already mentioned, nanoparticles have been found to improve the pore structure of conventional concrete, accelerate the C–S–H gel formation, and enhance the compressive and flexural strength as well as the durability of the cementitious matrix.[41] Similarly, the reinforcing ability of carbon nanotubes (CNT) and nanofibers was proven to substantially improve strength, the fracture characteristics and durability of cementitious nanocomposites [28, 42–45].

[28] achieved effective dispersion of CNTs by applying ultrasonic energy along with the use of a surfactant (SFC) and observed that beyond the necessity for ultrasonication, there is an optimum ratio of surfactant to CNTs for good dispersion.

More recently, Metaxa applied this dispersion method on four different types of CNFs and investigated the appropriate amount of ultrasonic energy and the surfactant to CNF ratio (SFC/CNF) for effective dispersion [45].
XRD of geopolymer pastes at 28 days with various nano-Al2O3 (1, 2, and 3%).[39] 14 S.

Konsta-Gdoutos studied the mechanical performance of the Multi-Walled Carbon Nanotube (MWCNT)/CNFs reinforced cement pastes by fracture mechanics tests on prismatic specimens of 20 × 20 × 80 mm.[28, 44] Before testing, a 6-mm notch was introduced to the specimens using a water-cooled diamond saw.

Konsta-Gdoutos studied the mechanical performance of the Multi-Walled Carbon Nanotube (MWCNT)/CNFs reinforced cement pastes by fracture mechanics tests on prismatic specimens of 20 × 20 × 80 mm.[28, 44] Before testing, a 6-mm notch was introduced to the specimens using a water-cooled diamond saw.
CMOD results using the two-parameter fracture model by Jenq and Shah [46].
Until now, the addition of the MWCNTs in cementitious matrices has resulted in either a decrease or smaller increase, up to 25%, of the flexural strength [47, 48].
Until now, the addition of the MWCNTs in cementitious matrices has resulted in either a decrease or smaller increase, up to 25%, of the flexural strength [47, 48].

Reasonably, the nanoindentation results can also provide an indirect method of estimating the volume fraction of the capillary pores.[49] It is observed from Figure 20 that the probability of Young’s modulus below 10 GPa, which corresponds to the porous phase, is significantly reduced for the samples with MWCNTs, indicating that the MWCNTs reduce the amount of fine pores by filling the area between the C–S–H gel.

The shrinkage development is known to be proportional to the amount of the fine pores (pores with diameter < 20 nm) in the binder at early ages.[50] Higher percentage of the volume fraction of small pores in a cementitious system at early ages leads to the increase of autogenous shrinkage.
